qas.question: Hormones can alter the sensitivity of the immune system, so they can be referred to as what?
Female sex hormones are immunostimulators of which immune responses?
What is an autoimmune disease that affects women preferentially?
What is the effect of testosterone on the male immune system?
What keeps the sensitivity of the immune system at the same levels?
When do autoimmune diseases often strike men?
What is a hormone that does not effect the immune system?
What male sex hormone is an immunostimulator?
What is an autoimmune disease that mostly strikes men?

context: <b4_0>Hormones<b4_0/> can act as <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>immunomodulators<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, altering the sensitivity of the immune system. For example, female sex hormones are known immunostimulators of <a1_1>both <a1_0><a1_2>adaptive and innate<a1_1/> immune responses<a1_2/><a1_0/>. Some autoimmune diseases such as <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b8_0>lupus erythematosus<b8_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> strike women preferentially, and their onset often coincides with <b5_0>puberty<b5_0/>. By contrast, male sex hormones such as <b7_0>testosterone<b7_0/> seem to be <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>immunosuppressive<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. Other hormones appear to regulate the immune system as well, most notably <b6_0>prolactin<b6_0/>, growth hormone and vitamin D.
